Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: threat or non-threat. Threatening someone means implying that someone will be hurt even if they do not do something specific.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Opening up people of a different race to violent acts including death by idiots, by inciting her followers to violence, is offensive. If anything happens to the Jones family, Dembroski should be charged as an accessory.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: I have the same view but I'm more cautious and skeptical of government policy and the ability of governments to fix problems.  I think in many cases government actually creates bigger problems (particularly in foreign policy, but also domestic policy) than it solves.  I can imagine a scenario where government policy to reduce emissions actually increases emissions over time because it increases the amount of time before better alternatives are brought to market.  

"Investing in green energy" really just means subsidizing certain politically-connected businesses to the detriment of others in much the same way that Hawaii's "dispensary" law was written.  Government simply cannot keep up with the rapid pace of technological progress in the 21st century.  It's too slow and inefficient.  It is a barrier to progress more than anything.  GMOs are a great example of this.  The only problem with GMOs are entirely created by the government (patents).

Comment: The other half of this article is the question of whether controlled-release really works for most patients and whether drugs like Oxycontin are really an improvement over morphine for pain management. The pattern of 12-hour larger doses instead of 4-hour smaller doses was heavily pushed to doctors by Purdue, despite mounting evidence that the drug couldn't control severe pain for that long and patients were increasing their use to compensate (which meant more sales).

http://www.latimes.com/projects/oxycontin-part1/

The modern history of opiates is one "less addictive!" claim after another, all equally false. It's potentially addictive because of the way it works, but most people who use opiates at some point don't become addicted because the drug effect interferes with the positive things in their life. If your life feels empty and hopeless, opiates are just one way you could fall down.

Think about it - there are 11 market sectors and the TSX is basically all in on just 3! Materials and Energy are 40% of a normalized (if there is such a thing) TSX market, financials another 30% +.
If you are a retiree, the materials and energy (commodity) sectors could be plus or minus a 50% return over the next 18 months! Is that any kind of retirement portfolio for a 65 year old? Who exposes a retiree's outcome to risk like that? 
Over a full cycle, Scott's attempts to diversify beyond the TSX will likely pay off. Editorial hubris aside, let's appluad any baby step toward basic common sense and making portfolios last...

Comment: "The Persian Gulf" is a big chunk of ocean and most current reports don't give anywhere enough specificity to make a judgment call on this.  The Daily Mail's article does have a graphic labeled "US Navy Handout" that shows an arrow and dot in the Strait of Hormuz.  Assume, for now, that's accurate.

Let's boil down a complicated history and set of claims.  Both Oman and Iran claim 12-mile territorial water boundaries, the effect of which is to leave no "international waters" in the Strait.  The US has not recognized these claims, and asserts the right of its warships to transit the Strait at will without giving notice.  The end result is basically a "might makes right" situation.

Almost all the recent confrontations have occurred in these disputed waters, but the exact location is critical.  Until then, we need to be careful about thumping our chests and threatening retaliation, because Iran does have the same right as any other nation to control its own waters.

Comment: The "problem" goes back as far as Rome, and probably further. The inexorable path of a civilization begins with subsistence, moves to production of simple goods, production of complex goods, development of advanced technology, production of goods requiring technology, and provision of services for the rest of the economy. With each stage, the preceding stage is outsourced to a less developed economy; the developing stage suffers a dislocation until those in the more advanced economy have the ability to accommodate that stage. Here, we have seen smokestack production outsourced while our economy flourishes in advanced industrial production, retail production  outsourced while innovation flourishes. The solution is not to "rage against the machine" but to take advantage of it. There are many things America does better than anywhere else in the world. Almost all of those require more "brainpower' than brawn. We lose jobs because we become more efficient. We must harness America's brains.

The businesslike thing to do would be to notify the applicant of these formatting issues and allow them to resubmit.  Tossing their apps aside without notice or recourse is pretty high-makamaka.

Comment: This article did bring out a couple of important points about the complexity of calculating actions. The sequestration concept is one that gets ignored when people look at only a very short term release. To compare the carbon input of lighting or fossil fuel that has been sequestered for millions of years to the short term ups and down that are measured in days to decades of agricultural activities is misleading.  When the long term sequestered products are added to the normal biological actives is where problems come in.
The ecological impact is also not accounted for.  The ecological impact of cutting rainforest for grazing is large but the replacement of grazers is small and may be positive in terms of ecology.  Many square miles of monoculture beans or oats is harmful to the environment so grass feed beef is better than feel lot beef but it may also be better for the environment than people consuming beans and oats from massive monoculture.

Comment: While I get that the theory of supply & demand predicts that increased property development will reduce housing prices, in real life it usually has the opposite effect.  Or at least that's what I've observed ... but of course like most economic theories, it can't ever be proven or disproven.

It does seem that every major stimulation of real-estate development is accompanied with a burst in market speculation, which draws a bunch of foreign money into the marketplace & drives up the price of everything. That might be the economics-based theory of why we don't see this supply/demand effect on housing that we keep hoping for.

I would love to see Oregon, or at least Portland, place a specific tariff on non-resident real estate investment, and use that to subsidize low-income housing.  Portland's buildings should be for Portland's citizens.  Young families shouldn't have to compete in a bidding war against billionaire speculators just to find a home.

Comment: This first hike in the BoE’s bank rate in more than a decade can be usefully compared to the first hike in our central bank’s overnight rate in almost seven years earlier in July. The BOE hike followed on the inflation rate rising to 3.0% in September, and forecast to rise above the upper bound to 3.2% in October. The BoC hike followed on the inflation rate falling to 1.3% in May from 1.6% in April. The inflation rate fell again, to 1.0% in June, at the lower bound of the BoC’s target range.

Comment: Somerset lies: a bump-fire stock will not allow a semi-automatic AR15 style rifle to fire at the same rate as a fully-automatic machine gun. It will approximate the rate of fire of an automatic rifle. 

If you need to know the difference:
A bump fire stock increases the rate of fire of a semi-automatic rifle to about 400 rounds per minute.  
A C8 automatic rifle like our Canadian Infantry uses have a cyclic rate of 750 to 950 rounds per minute. 
What remains unspoken in the discussion is that both of the above rates are limited by how the cartridges are fed into the gun: a 30-round magazine, which is standard capacity on an AR15, would be empty in seconds and require replacement. A C8 operates so on a 100-round drum or is fed by a disintegrating belt.
The lightest machine guns, like the M249 Squad Automatic Weapon, are substantially heavier than an infantry weapon. They have rates of fire of 800 rounds per minute, while heavy (typically mounted) machine guns have a lower rate of fire.

Comment: There remains one unspoken element to this story. Why did the broker recommend the sale of these assets? 

There must have been a reason that appeared sound at the time. Was there a need to sell assets? Was there a choice of which to sell and which to keep? What did the investor do with the proceeds of the sales? Was the money invested in other assets? If so then did those assets gain in value?

It is very easy to blame a stock broker for one's losses while ignoring one's own complicity in the affair. Stock brokers exist to facilitate asset sales. Their inherent conflict of interest makes them a poor choice for medium or long term investment advice.

In the interests of frustrating the raving loonies reading this post who would like to accuse me of coddling stock brokers, I am not a stock broker.

We have a spending of allocated funds problem.

Comment: I looked up the polls and according to Gallup (which has been asking the same question since 1992) as of January 3 2017, 36% of Americans self-identify as conservative, and 27% are liberal. However it's not that simple: 34% identify as moderate, and since 1992 conservatives have dropped fairly steadily from 42% to 36% while moderates have remained more or less the same, sometimes making up a higher percent than conservatives; and liberals have increased from 17% in 1992 to 27% this year. Some moderates are bound to be more conservative, some more liberal.  As I said it depends on where you stand - I consider myself to be more moderate than liberal, while you might think I'm a flaming liberal. Believe me, I'm not! For instance, I think health care for all is a position everyone could get behind, while privatization of all schools is a radical approach, just as public ownership of all newspapers would be a radical concept. The free market decides which media survive, and their politics.

Comment: Two points.
First, the battle with the provinces demonstrates why the federal government should get out of providing any funding other than equalization payments.  The provinces have all the same taxing powers of the federal government except for import duties but they also collect all the money from lotteries.  Of course, to stop funding the provinces the federal government needs to drop their taxes by exactly the amount of the cut in transfers or it will be nothing but a huge tax grab.  By having the federal government inserting itself into provincial funding simply increases the bureaucracy of both to monitor and report on the spending.
Second, provinces are mature forms of government that are responsible to the voting public.  If the residents of the province doesn't like what the provincial government is doing, it can vote them out.  Hence it makes perfect sense to provide equalization payments with no strings attached.

Comment: The only member of the MPC to vote for a rate hike was the American Kristin Forbes, who is on her way out.
Piovano writes: “The Bank of England predicts the annual inflation rate will rise to 2.7 per cent by the middle of this year, up from the current rate of 2.3 per cent and pushing the official limit of close to 2 per cent.” He meant to write “The Bank of England projects the annual inflation rate will rise to 2.7 per cent in April and May, pushing the official upper bound of three per cent”. The BoE actually forecasts the rate will drop to 2.6 per cent in June. The current target inflation indicator of the BoE is dysfunctional because it excludes house prices, and the new ONS headline inflation measure, CPIH, isn't much better. It includes homeownership costs but also excludes house prices. Right now the best monthly inflation measure for central bank purposes is the RPI excluding mortgage interest and council tax. It  already rose by 2.7% in March, as in February.

Comment: To put the Chief Justice's career in perspective, she was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1989.  Not only has every judge who was on the court when she joined it been replaced, but their replacements (and in some cases their replacements' replacements) have also been replaced.  She's a singular figure in the judiciary, the longest-serving Chief Justice, and one of the best -- if you compare her tenure to some of her predecessors, she was far better at locating consensus than the sometimes fractious courts in the years immediately after the Charter.

The next Chief Justice will, based on precedent, most likely be Justice Abella (the senior puisne justice has been appointed in all but four cases, and two of those were slightly modified seniority; only twice has seniority been thrown out entirely), while the new puisne justice, drawn from the West, will give Trudeau the opportunity to add greater diversity to the bench that he clearly wanted with the Atlantic seat but couldn't manage.

Canada has long been a lousy free-trader when it comes to areas like medical services, agricultural products, or simply subsidizing favoured businesses with government grants.  And the US has tired of being the market for all of the worlds cheap goods.  But as the playing field shifts, we are still in the best position to take advantage of the US market, especially if we keep our mouth shut and don't get all preachy about our neighbours.

Comment: "Dusendschon thinks Caldwell has been doing a good job regarding rail. He said it’s similar to the H3 interstate project, which also had a lot of detractors when it was being built."

H-3 cannot be compared to rail. I was surprised to also hear Sen Michelle Kidani use this same fallacy at the Legislature's Sine Die this year.

H-3 was a federal project funded by the federal government paying about 80%-90% of its costs.

Honolulu Rail has the federal government paying only a FIXED $1.55 Billion. Oahu pays for the UNKNOWN construction balance and forever maintenance/operations costs.

H-3 has NO rail stations or cabooze or box fares or security etc to manage and service.

H-3 exercised eminent domain along its route line. Honolulu Rail exercises eminent domain along its route lin but its best-kept secret is future eminent domain aka "land assembly" along the 21 sq. mile Transit Oriented Development (TOD) corridor! Private properties can be easily seized for "public/private partnerships."

Comment: It's possible I have been misled by media, but equally possible that you have also.  If 15% of the population being uninsured is an acceptable figure based on someone’s standard, I won’t argue with it.  It’s just that my own standard is higher; I think all citizens are entitled to a reasonable standard of health care.

Certain services are better delivered by the private sector.  Others are more suited to the government.  In my mind, these include such things as roads, schools, and health care.  

In terms of the figures I cited, no, they don’t drill down into medical tourism.  They are just per capita figures supplied by the World Bank.  I don’t pretend to know how many medical tourists enter the US each year, but I don’t believe it is in the millions.

All that said, each of us is entitled to an opinion.  These are not simple issues with cookie-cutter solutions. And I believe there has been a certain amount of misinformation disseminated on both sides.

Comment: I only used maths to demonstrate that there are many areas (not limited to maths) where one answer is held to be correct to the exclusion of all others...I did not intend for it to be entirely analogous to the basis of religious belief...because maths, rather uniquely, can use its own internal rules of logic to prove further rules of logic...however, that said, even maths is dependent on holding to fundamental, unprovable axioms. Furthermore, most of our lives is lived outside of a realm of rigorous proof: you can't prove that your mother loves you (in the same way that you can prove a mathematical theorem - you can only draw conclusions on the basis of past experiences), you can't prove what your favourite music is etc...in fact most of our daily actions are informed by our past experience, rather than by following some rigorous mathematical-style proof or logic....and basing future actions on past experience is a form of faith!

Comment: Thank you, Ms Alfonso, for highlighting the critical nature of this teacher shortage, particularly in BC. I would like to point out that there are a number of possible ways to invite French teachers who have moved from immersion into the English stream as well as encourage strong core French teachers to move into immersion, such as providing subsidies to take French language immersive courses to boost their proficiency and share promising practices with other French second language educators. One great example of this is UBC’s Institut de français in Quebec City (http://quebec.frenchcentre.ubc.ca) where, for 25 years, teachers have been continuing their professional learning in the summer. School district subsidies to supplement what provincial governments can provide could be very helpful.
Wendy Carr, Associate Dean, Teacher Education, UBC

Comment: TOO MUCH carbon dioxide is changing the climate.  Those large quantities of carbon dioxide are being produced by human activity, namely the heavy burning of fossil fuels (coal, gasoline, etc.). When it was only a matter of plants consuming CO2 and animals producing CO2 by their respiration, things were in balance.  Once humans had figured out how to control and manage fire, we started producing extra CO2.  For most of human history, the amounts of CO2 produced by human activity were still pretty small.  However, in modern times, we have figured out how to utilize VERY concentrated sources of carbon, namely coal and petroleum, to produce energy.  This results in the release of larger quantities of CO2 into the atmosphere which tends to hold in the heat of the sun and prevent it from radiating back out into space.  This extra heat, in turn, is  changing the climate of the earth, making some areas dryer and less suited to agriculture.

Comment: You're taking an extremely optimistic view of things there Mark.

Will electric vehicles be mainly charged at off-peak hours?  That's a good theory and it might even hold up in reality, though I haven't seen it studied yet.  This is somewhat odd to me as there are enough electric cars out there to get at least a rough approximation of when people actually DO charge their electric cars rather than when people think they should charge them.

I would toss out a guess that MOST owners of electric vehicles will mostly plug them in when they get home from work, probably at about 5pm.  If so that would be a BIG problem because that closely aligns with peak electricity demand summer months.  Obviously there are some simple technical changes that could help here, but are they being used?  Note that I did not say "CAN they be used?", but "ARE they being used?"

Comment: Since pesticides are poisons, shouldn't we disclose & monitor when/where they're routinely applied and when/where hazardous levels are confirmed?  Hopefully, common sense will prevail instead of concern for corporate profits or political careers.  We're responsible for protecting our children and environment from these hazards & we can't do that without this much-needed data.  

Several studies have found household dust in homes on or near soils impacted by persistent pesticides is much more contaminated than outdoor soils. It's attributed to all the persistent pesticides tracked & blown into homes that become trapped in enclosed spaces, enabling higher & higher concentrations to accumulate inside homes over time. These studies suggest those who live on or near pesticide-impacted soils or agricultural areas where persistent pesticides are or have been used may be at risk of harmful pesticide exposures inside their homes year-round, whether pesticides are being applied or not.

Comment: Well, there are some interesting "facts" that shed light on the political and "tale of two cities" aspects.

The electoral district within which the building is located was called Regent's Park and Kensington North until 2010.    The constituency covered the areas of St John's Wood, Maida Vale, the Harrow Road, Westbourne Green, Maida Hill, Little Venice, parts of Queen's Park, parts of Ladbroke Grove and Notting Hill as well as North Kensington.

When the boundaries of the district were redrawn to become "Kensington" in 2010, it then encompassed the best known areas of Kensington further south, but not Chelsea.  So, there is, as of 2010, a Parliamentary district called Kensington, which includes Grenfell Tower.

Separately, there is an administrative Borough (municipal district) called Kensington and Chelsea, which also seems to include Grenfell Tower at its very northern tip.   Kensington and Chelsea is where administration for the building safety would be done, not "Kensington".

Comment: By the time Jim Bookey was solidly in Anchorage one of his more curious TV commercials was when he and some other cohort were shown outdoors in winter harvesting potatoes by hand from the snow.

I remember Bookeys near Kenai, beside a small ball field where the local sports teams from various KPBSD schools would meet as part of the borough-wide school sports; smaller schools from as far away as Seward would individually in private cars, drive the teams to these events. Some as far away as Ninilchik, for basketball competition. Other times Kenai or more remote (from Seward) Homer.

We had Bookey's fare after playing baseball in the nearby field, before the roadtrip back toward Seward, in the early fall in the late 1960s. The trip was slower back then, as folks generally traveled under the speed limit, and roads designed for 45-50MPH.

It was a treat; food & service was good. Haven't been into Bookeys or Wee Bees since..! ;)

Comment: This is just the tip of the iceberg. A cavalier attitude to materials safety in the 20th century has already killed many and left an enormous legacy contamination. The peril of asbestos, the "miracle mineral", has persisted longer than lead or UFFI,  and still lurks in many 20th-century public, commercial, and residential buildings. The danger varies according to material form, but none of it is safe unless encapsulated air-tight or completely removed. Remediation workers wear haz-mat suits and the work area is sealed off with plastic. Commercial operations pay for their own remediation. We taxpayers no doubt pay to remediate public buildings. But what about homeowners who cannot possibly afford such work? What about tenants?

Comment: While it's a new and entertaining idea, both companies are gonna have to survive on company outings and other special event revenue. This is not going be a hot place to go for the Friday and Saturday night bar crowds. It's $35 a person. Most of the downtown bar goers are working class people and $35 is 6-8 drinks to them (enough to get them drunk or well on their way). Also it's hard to find a group of 4 people where all of them will be willing to make that kind of a financial commitment, especially if the establishment lacks a liquor license (as they currently do). Bad Axe is located at 270 and I25. That means it's not a quick walk or drive to get there from LoDo. It's a commitment that some will make a couple times, but probably not enough to become regular customers. I wish the companies well, but I don't expect either to last very long.

Comment: Ranger, focusing on the message: If you think NOAA’s data is suspect, look at NASA, UK Met. Office, Japanese Met. Agency, and BerkelyEarth. Comment: Using Sea Ice Extent as a metric is literally just looking at the surface of the situation. Antarctic Sea Ice Volume has been declining at 1% a year for decades. That is slower than the 3% annual decline in the Arctic, but it still translates into enough lost ice to cover millions of sq km of ocean if it were spread 1 meter thick. In the Arctic the 20 meter multi year pressure ridges that forced the MV Manhattan to give up on the McClure Parry passage in 1968 and 1969 are gone, replaced by thin single seasonal ice that melts away during the summer, just as Seasonal Antarctic Ice melts away in December and January.

Comment: "Which was better for the average American and creating great long lasting jobs? The 40 years after the New Deal or the 40 years after the Reagan revolution?"
.
It won't be "40 years after the Reagan revolution" until 2028. The New Deal ended in 1942 (effectively at the end of 1941), so the 40 years after that would run through 1981, and include the chaotic years of WWII and the immediate postwar years. Then there is the issue of what constitutes a "great" job. Does a tedious, but well paid, factory job count? 
.
We can look at the patterns of the majority of those periods, however. From 1951 through 1981, net private sector job growth accelerated, with increasing median levels of pay and benefits, and high average job retention. From 1981 to 2009, net private sector job growth slowed (and then went negative), with decreasing levels of median pay and benefits and declining average job retention. The post-New Deal period wins hands down.

Comment: Murkowski's complaint about ANWR becoming a monument has little to no connection with the residents of the islands wanting a sanctuary around their homes and requesting one. An ANWR monument would not violate ANILCA because ANILCA specifically exempted areas set aside prior to 1980. ANWR was set aside in 1960. Further, the 'no more clause' in ANILCA would not survive close examination by the courts, who have held since 1920 that large monuments are permitted, and that the size of the monument is the presidents call. Monuments in ANWR and Bristol Bay will be upheld, under Supreme Court precedent, and the fact AK has no standing to challenge any monuments in its borders , under Alaska vs Carter (1980). It is the courts, not Congress, that determine the legality of actions by the presidents, in the case of monuments, the courts have upheld every monument ever challenged, including all 17 of Carters. Likewise any monuments Obama creates will be upheld.

Comment: Only time will tell if Gorsuch is what he claims to be or not. For people who are whining about Merrick Garland, the simple fact is, Obama lack the popular mandate to appoint such a judge. By lacking the popular mandate, I am talking about Congressional control. The Constitution is very clear that the President can appoint someone to the Supreme Court but the Senate have the authority to "advice and consent" on that nomination. Ironically, the Constitution doesn't force the Senate to act on that nomination and if they choose NOT to "advice and consent", they can do that as they have done so in the past with Republican or Democratic nominees. In general theory, there is no reason to denied Gorsuch his appointment. Even the Democrats acknowledge that he is a superbly qualified but it matter of politics as it always been in the past. Its his stance on issues, not his qualifications that determined the votes. I am sure this will swing both ways, as it always done in the past.

Comment: That is the single most ignorant statement I have read today. Implying that a single man is responsible for the economic structure of the world is ridiculous. The economy works on a supply and demand, it's just that simple. The Demand that is growing is for alternative energy sources to fossil fuels. Holding on to something as it goes down a drain gets harder as the pull of the drain increases. The world IS moving away from fossil fuel, and that WILL be the future. It is only those profiting in the short term that are fighting it. A tipping point will be reach , and the inevitable will occur. Comment: In the article, a person attending the concert made this claim (as supporting the idea that the photographer's behaviour was offensive): "There's a certain understanding that if an artist asks a crowd to do something ... the artist is in charge in that space". An interesting suggestion, but I think it is, quite simply, false. If a performer asks the crowd to clap along, must they comply because the artist is in charge in that space? Not at all, because the artist is _not_ in charge of _that_ space (they are of the stage, presumably) Is it rude if they don't? Not at all; the artist 'asks', she doesn't 'demand'. And if one chooses not to comply with a request, one is not, by that fact alone, guilty of being rude or offensive.

Comment: This news story has generated more letters, comments, articles, etc. than any other that I can remember in my 40 years in Eugene. Most have been thoughtful, honest, insightful, and have given me a lot to think about - particularly in regards to my own biases, both the ones I know and those I don't even know that I have. No matter how much I read, talk, watch, experience, empathize with, etc, I will never know what it is like to be Black, a Woman, a Jew, Gay, etc. I will never be able to fully know what it is like to be anyone else other than myself, and no one else will ever know what it is like to be me.  
I doubt we'll ever be able to fully and collectively bridge the racial divides and prejudices in this country. We don't seem to be able to learn from our collective past without being labeled by it and stuck in it. Since I can't change it, I say live in the present and treat yourself and fellow human with as much dignity, integrity, understanding, civility, etc. as you can muster.

Comment: The "spirit" of Alaska is death. Kill, kill, kill, as though killing is some sort of sacred activity.  People complain about violent crime, and want to link it to everything but the ugly truth.

Comment: Here’s to hope, Alicia!

In the lifetime of some of us it truly was as you hope it can be.  

I was baptized with perhaps 20 early teens at a service exclusively dedicated to baptism on a Sabbath afternoon in 1957.  I was 13 years old.  We had all been instructed in a baptismal class, a catechism of Seventh-day Adventist answers from Scripture to common spiritual questions.  What is God like?  What are we like?  What is the Seventh-day Adventist church like?

As I recall, my membership was a matter of, having come to understand how Seventh-day Adventists were coming to answer the spiritual questions covered in the class, was I willing to accept an invitation to be a member, subject to my baptism.  

And baptizing us, every minister simply said the same thing:  ‘Because you have accepted Jesus as your savior, I now baptize you …’

Simple.  Respectful.  Welcoming.

Comment: Otto, 

Immediately upon addition to drinking water, fluorosilicates (FS) completely hydrolyze (dissociate) into fluoride ions, identical to those which have always existed in water, and trace contaminants in barely detectable amounts far below EPA mandated maximum allowable levels.  After this point, the FS  no longer exists in that water.  It does not reach the tap.  It is not ingested.  It is, therefore, of no concern, whatsoever.

FS has not been approved by anyone as a "medical treatment".  They are not ingested.

The  relative toxicity of FS is irrelevant.  They are not ingested.

Calcium fluoride (CaF2) does not occur in groundwater.  "Naturally occurring" fluoride is fluoride ions leached from CaF2 and fluorosilicates in rocks as groundwater passes over these rocks. These "naturally occurring" F ions are identical to those released by FS during fluoridation. A  F ion is a F ion, regardless the source compound from which it is released.


Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: rowbat: I think misconceptions have been allowed to go unchallenged in this debate. Some believe that child soldiers who are 15 to 17 years of age are immune from prosecution and/or punishment for war crimes. There is no such broad prohibition in international law, only restrictions stipulating that they can't be jailed for life or executed. So, there's nothing inherently improper or illegal about jailing a child combatant and in fact Khadr's incarceration continued upon his return to Canada as a function of the repatriation agreement. That Khadr was subjected to torture raises a separate issue, but I wonder whether Canada had much real influence in this matter as he was a U.S. prisoner. Canada no doubt could have done more to repatriate Khadr but Harper's approach of not being particularly interventionist on behalf of Canadians incarcerated and even sentenced to death by the U.S. justice system was fairly consistently applied.

And if they're not flaunting that, why hassle them over their leggings?

Of course, being Hawaiian I don't like the "barefoot" prohibition either.  Is it a question of safety?  Then I submit there have been a lot more injuries caused by wearing high heels.  Try going through an emergency exit and walking along the wing, or going down an evacuation slide, in stilettos.  Is it a question of beauty norms?  Healthy feet are beautiful feet.  The gnarliest toes I've ever seen are the ones crammed inside tight and pointy shoes for years.  

Besides, going barefoot will get you through the TSA checkpoint quicker.  I've heard of shoe bombs -- but foot bombs, never!

Comment: Richard, now you've conceded that municipal bylaws are also subject to the Charter -  but have made a categorical statement that if it's the result of a residents' vote, the Charter doesn't apply.  That's even more wrong.

Bylaws and their amendments are government actions subject to the Charter, whether they are voted in by residents or elected municipal councillors.

The principle comes up often in labour law:
"neither can a trade union blindly rely on a vote of its members against taking a grievance to arbitration. Such a vote result will not save a union [when] the circumstances are such that the vote should have been given little or no weight (as in perhaps the case of a very unpopular employee, for example)."

As the SCC wrote about fundamental freedoms in another context:
"The ultimate determination must be with the courts, because they provide what is often the only effective shelter for individuals and unpopular minorities from the shifting winds of public passion."

Comment: My grandfather--with one small kid (my Dad) and another on the way (my uncle)--worked like it was a "gig economy" ...in 1925. Not those guys (Grandfather worked until he died; father-in-law managed to save enough during the last decade of his career.)  I didn't start saving until 1986, (age 40,) probably for many of the same reasons wage-slaves in corporate cubicles don't--kids, cars, mortgages and--too frequently--alimony and/or child-support. 

Anybody who works for themselves better...
1.  Stop calling it "free-lance."  Think "professional" or close up shop.

2. Stop doing it "part-time."  To be successful, you'll work longer and harder than any 9-5er.

Comment: The objectors to Humanae Vitae never reached the point where they could write of "correction" or "heresy" since both of these have an implicit reference to the constant teaching of the Church.  There was an extra step for HV dissenters since it looked like they were asking for a break from tradition.

After Humanae Vitae there was vigorous discussion.  Which is still ongoing, to some extent.

Some made the clericalist appeal to authority.  But that time around the dissenters counted in their number the in-crowd, the Massimo Faggiolis and James Martins of their day (who could, like M. Faggioli, sometimes substitute snobbery for argument and get away with it.).  They started from a position of strength and moved to one of weakness due among other things to the development of analytical Thomism (didn't Liz Anscombe contribute?) and the further presentation of the Theology of the Body.  Advances in biology and medicine further strengthened the argument in favor of HV.

Comment: The concern about the downtown area is that much of it is built on fill sluiced down from the post office hill, so when things start shaking liquefaction will cause those buildings to collapse. Many of those buildings had their original ground floors buried as a result (been on an underground tour?) so they may actually be stronger as a result, but building codes for seismic resistance are relatively new, so get out of downtown if you can. The tribe's architects no doubt will take this into consideration, and footings will be dug deeper than the fill. They'll probably be safer than the old buildings. Any wave that survives crashing on the hook will likely dissipate a lot of its strength there, but pilings along the shore will still be a good idea to knock down any waves that make it across the harbor. The tribe's  hotel will cater to gamblers coming to be shuttled out to their rez casino so the added risk of sleeping in a tsunami zone may actually be attractive to them. ;-)

Comment: A few years ago I worked with the then Director for Center for Alaska Coastal Studies on preserving the 2 beaches near their field station for tide pooling activities for the school children of Alaska. It was in response to the increase in clamming activities in the area. New visitors in the area not being familiar would dig for clams on these beaches not being aware that this was not an abundant area for clams and the beaches were being hit heavily because they were accessible by small boats.  I worked for almost 2 years gathering all the information and support to make a case to the Alaska Department of Fish and Game why the beaches needed to be protected.  The information was submitted and the next step was to attend the Board of Fisheries and then I went to the meeting and spoke my 5 minutes in support. I was indeed a "curiosity" since no one had ever proposed that in this state before. 3 days later the Board of Fisheries approved the measure and it was a now a state law.

Comment: As usual, the issue is conflated and polarized. Agenda driven journalism.

The old rule put in place by Obama required the Social Security Aministration to report to the national background check system people on full mental disability benefits, including veterans with PTSD. In fact, the State of California started going around sending police SWAT teams to residences of registered gun owning veterans with PTSD who were then flagged on the FBI's background check system . 

Obama's law also reinforced the stereotype that people with mental illnesses are violent, which is not true in the vast number of cases, according to the ACLU, that objected to Obama's law; in fact, people with mental illnesses are more likely to be victims of violence. The new law does not totally eliminate the restriction: only reduces the number of illnesses under which the ban applies, by not automatically disqualifying those on full social disability benefits. The latter included those with eating disorders.

Comment: The authors are on the right topic but they are barking up the wrong tree with their solution.

What we are seeing in at least North America, is similar to the breakup of "Ma Bell" in the United States into separate companies.  At this point, the competition in the internet space itself is causing inefficiency and higher prices.  Allow me to explain.

The big players, Telus, Shaw, Rogers, and some regional players, are all building their own fibre backbone infrastructure.  That means from Montreal to Vancouver, you have at least 3 major fibre pipes with spans of shorter running practically in parallel.  The same players are in the mobile space, again, developing infrastructure which is duplicated.  This is why Wind and Mobilicity can't compete.

The solution is to use anti-trust regulation to break up the backbone segments and the endpoint segments into distinct businesses.  The backbone segments can sell bandwidth to anyone, and the endpoint vendors buy from the backbone.  Solution.

Comment: You ask: "When will Monsanto grow food we can eat (rather) than seed crops?" 

I can't speak to Monsanto in particular, but the big ag industry does a lot to assist diversified ag -- which grows a lot of our local produce. For example, Pioneer helped to upgrade the water filters for the Wailua aqueduct a few years back. Without that, smaller-scale farmers in the area wouldn't be able to keep operating. 

I'm sure we can find other ways the big ag corporations help the little ag producers. For example, on Molokai Monsanto (used to) do all the work to keep the Farmers' football field in good condition. They also dug the graves for departed Molokai residents. Also important, for Molokai at least, are the jobs Monsanto provided. Now that they've left, a lot of Molokai families are turning more and more to hunting, foraging, and gathering to feed themselves. This is great, yes, but there are serious doubts about whether Molokai's environment can handle this onslaught. 

Just a few positives

Comment: Harper and the Conservatives waited until the started of the 2015/16 fiscal year to sell their shares in GM so that the proceeds were booked during that year.

The budget was balanced the previous year in 2014/15 without any significant asset sales.

Hindsight being 20/20 it looks like the Federal government actually sold at an EXCELLENT time in early April 2015.  The share price at that point had just recently declined a bit from a recent-era peak in U.S. dollars (and the highest point ever for 'new GM' in Canadian dollars), a peak that remains the high-water mark to this day.  There was a very brief period in late 2016/early 2017 where the share price very slightly exceeded what the Federal government received, but only by about 1 or 2% and it has since fallen down about 10%.

Considering this was a leveraged investment it cost us money every day we held those shares, so selling near a peak a few years ago had paid dividends for Federal coffers.

Comment: "The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is warning people that a daily aspirin regimen may not help prevent a heart attack or stroke, and may cause dangerous bleeding into the BRAIN or stomach.

Although a daily low dose of aspirin has been shown to be effective in preventing a reoccurrence of a heart attack or stroke, the FDA is now warning people who have not had a first heart attack or stroke that taking an aspirin every day may not have a benefit. In fact, doing so may actually cause serious side effects.

However, following examination of scientific data from major studies, the FDA has concluded that the data do not support the use of aspirin as a preventive medication by people who have not had a heart attack, stroke, or cardiovascular problems, a use that is known as primary prevention. In these people, the benefit has not been established, and risks, such as dangerous bleeding into the BRAIN or stomach, are still present." 
                FDA, 2014

There was a massive pipe organ that drowned out everything from the back pew to the high altar. It was more important to see the priest during the homily than to hear him. The rosary people pressed on regardless through to the final amen.

Enter...Vatican II, Liturgical reform, Mass in vernacular, facing the assembly... but no one can really remedy the church structures/buildings that were never designed for -- full active conscious participation in the liturgy and have merely been 'adapted' to that purpose. New constructions take that in a bit more.  
I waited to see if someone would recognize Vatican II factor.

Comment: I'm against the motion M-103 because of the inclusion, and because of the irrational resistance to removing, the word Islamophobia from the motion. Islamophobia, which is not defined in the motion, could mean simply a dislike of the religion of Islam, or a dislike of certain aspects of the religion of Islam. Should a legitimate and critical opinion about a religion, or about certain aspects of a religion, be condemned along with racism or bigotry, which are both unambiguously undesirable attitudes about or towards other people?

For example, a person may feel that the Islamic burqa is an obstacle to integration in society, or they may feel it is discriminatory against women and girls. Right or wrong, should this be called Islamophobia, and, more to the point, should this person be condemned and put in the same bucket as racists and bigots?

Comment: There are too many errors in your assertions to address them all individually, and the war ended over 152 years ago. New York (named after the most prosperous slave owner and trader in American history) was the last Northern state to end slavery, but slave ships sailed from Northern ports and continued to do so even after the Civil War ended, hauling slaves sold by blacks and Muslims in Africa all over the world. Comment: As a former VPSO, I can tell you that it is a very big deal to law enforcement.  Fully 99+% of my calls were in some way related to alcohol.  We actively sought out bootleggers, and confiscations do occur, especially on felony-level importation.  I know of at least one now-VPSO craft that was foreited by a bootlegger.  

The problem is that for every avenue you shut down, a new one crops up.  Shut down the bootleggers and new ones spring up to fill the void and in the time it takes them to get up and running, someone else is making homebrew.  That's because we have the same underlying problem that made Prohibition fail; the demand is simply strong enough to overpower the enforcement and interdiction efforts against it.  Without creating a totalitarian regieme that breaks the Bill of Rights in more ways that I can count, that won't change.

Comment: "The state regulates for the most part, not bans."

Specious. A clothing choice is regulated in the sense of it being banned when accessing government services, just as cigarettes are regulated in the sense of being banned in certain locations. 

Semantic tricks aside, the difference between a niqab ban and your examples is that restrictions on cigarette use, or lying in court, are justified on more fundamental principles of governance. You can't smoke on the bus because it infringes on the rights of others to have a smoke-free ride. Perjury is a "crime against justice" because it compromises the integrity of the judicial process. There is no comparable legal principle upon which restrictions on clothing choice can be based.
